Award.AwardTitle: DMREF: SusChEM: Simulation-Based Predictive Design of All-Organic Phosphorescent Light-Emitting Molecular Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
DMREF: SUSCHEM: SIMULATION-BASED PREDICTIVE DESIGN OF ALL-ORGANIC PHOSPHORESCENT LIGHT-EMITTING MOLECULAR MATERIALS

Non-technical Description: Organic light emitting diodes (OLED) exhibit remarkable energy efficiency in applications ranging from urban lighting to large-screen display panels. Current technologies are based on phosphorescent materials that contain organo-metallic compounds, which involve heavy-metal ions. These are expensive to procure, present limitations with regard to device longevity, and in some cases are considered environmentally unsafe or even toxic. The goal of this research is to eliminate the need for heavy-metal ions by developing a fundamentally new class of all-organic phosphorescent molecules. The principal task is to design molecules in which the juxtaposition of electronic orbitals promotes the processes underlying phosphorescence while at the same time the chemical bonding patterns provide the structural rigidity needed to minimize the non-radiative decay of electronic excitations. To this end an integrative computational-experimental approach is employed, in which molecular simulations, chemical synthesis, and materials characterization are combined in a synergistic and iterative sequence. The expected outcomes of this project are novel environmentally benign phosphorescent materials that are based on sustainable chemistries and that are immediately deployable for lighting applications. The new insights into the functional response of molecular materials gained while perfecting metal-free OLED benefits organic electronics in general, and advance technologies such as photovoltaics, sensors, and displays. Finally, software toolkits, data management utilities, and workflows for simulation-based predictive materials design are established as a new paradigm for materials development.

Technical Description: The efficiency of phosphorescent materials is based on the ability to emit not only from singlet but also triplet excited states, which are populated as a result of spin-orbit coupling. The strength of this coupling is attributed to the presence of heavy-metal ions in organo-metallic compounds. However, organo-metallics are accompanied by significant challenges: besides the high cost of precious metals, dislocated metal ions in the emitting layer may trap charge, which jeopardizes device longevity. By serendipity, the co-PI demonstrated metal-free organic phosphors with unprecedented high solid-state phosphorescent quantum yield of up to 68% at ambient conditions. The current research aims to further develop this fundamentally new, environmentally benign, and chemically sustainable class of all-organic phosphorescent molecules with improved performance characteristics by employing an integrated computational-experimental approach. Specific objectives are to (i) eliminate the heavy metal ions form the emitting molecules with the aim to lower materials cost and obtainability, improve ease of fabrication, and prolong device lifetime and dependability; (ii) deconvolute the dual roles of halogen bonding, i.e., to promote spin-orbit coupling and suppress vibrational energy dissipation, and supplant the intermolecular secondary bonding-induced phosphorescence enhancement mechanism with intramolecular analogs; (iii) optimize the molecular architectures of both the emitting and host species so as to minimize vibration-mediated non-radiative decay of excited states through stiffening of intramolecular bonding patterns, stabilization of emitters by host molecules designed to suppress detrimental vibrations within effectively packed geometries, and crystallization of emitters within nano-confinement. To this end, concept emitter and host molecules are constructed and their structure and electronic properties, e.g., excited state energies, singlet-triplet transition rates, charge mobilities, etc., predicted using first-principles calculations. Structural models are generated using shape packing algorithms and molecular simulations, and possible crystal structures are predicted. Best candidate molecules are synthesized, characterized, and their emissive and vibrational properties measured.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The efficiency of organic light emitting diodes (OLED) is determined by the energy levels electrons can be excited into and the pathways along which they can cascade downward while releasing energy as radiation. The excited states available to electrons depend on the structure of the organic molecule, its environment, and the electronic configuration of specific atoms present in the molecule. In this respect, heavy-metal ions play a key role in opening additional decay routes for excited electrons through a mechanism based on magnetic interactions between the electron’s own spin and that of the orbital it circulates on. Consequently, organo-metallic molecules are prevalent in phosphorescent OLED materials.  However, organo-metallics are accompanied by significant challenges: besides the high cost of precious metals, dislocated metal ions in the emitting layer may trap charge and color fade, which jeopardizes device longevity. These metallic elements are often rare, expensive, toxic, or otherwise burdensome to the environment. By serendipity, co-PI Kim demonstrated metal-free organic phosphors with unprecedented high solid-state phosphorescent quantum yield of up to 68% at ambient conditions. Elaborating on this discovery, the present research resulted in further development of this fundamentally new, environmentally benign, and chemically sustainable class of all-organic phosphorescent molecules with improved performance characteristics by employing an integrated computational-experimental approach.

Intellectual merit — We have successfully developed a computational workflow for the predictive design of all-organic phosphorescent and TADF molecules.  Computation purposely precedes synthesis and characterization, allowing for the numerical exploration of dozens of molecular designs in a fraction of the time it would take to do this in the laboratory, so as to identify the most promising candidates for a target application before synthesis routes are identified. Using this approach, we have clearly established the mechanism responsible for phosphorescence in all-organic molecules: halide groups play the most critical role in that they establish halogen bonding between molecules and facilitate spin-orbit coupling. Carbonyl groups or other functional groups such as chlorides can be used to control phosphorescent properties due to the variation in the heavy atom effect. With a few exceptions, heavier halide atoms have stronger heavy atom effect.

Luminescent materials are used for lighting, imaging, and sensing, and therefore must achieve intense fluorescence or phosphorescence, and sensitivity to environmental factors. To effect rational design of materials with target performance criteria we have established a molecular platform for the development of hybrid fluorescent/phosphorescent single-molecule emitters that enables us to design state of the art sensing and imaging devices within one easily tunable molecular framework. We have successfully used this platform for the conception of new molecular systems that exhibit thermally activated delayed fluorescence with narrow emission spectra. Furthermore, we have developed an oxygen-sensor for bio-medical applications based onpurely organic phosphors configured as core-shell nanoparticles and demonstrated a very high sensitivity for dissolved oxygen. By eliminating toxicity issues associated with leaching of heavy metals from organometallics, our materials are particularly attractive for use in wearable bio-sensing and monitoring devices.

Broader impacts — Six graduate students, three postdoctoral researchers, and one visiting student have been trained in the ways of conducting scientific research, reviewing the scientific literature critically, analytical and creative thinking, and the systematic pursuit of scientific discovery. The students and postdoctoral researchers have developed a range of experimental and computational skills. The development of sustainable chemistries for advanced technological applications bears significant benefits for the environment and healthy human living conditions, while at the same time facilitating the advancement of the quality of life through new health monitoring technologies.

We participated in the conception and organization of the Materials Camp for high school teachers, sponsored by the ASM International Foundation, which is held every summer at the University of Michigan Ann Arbor campus since 2002. Typically, 20 high school teachers from across the nation partake in this camp and learn about materials science and engineering in order to convey information about this field to their students. We are also now launching a MS-to-PhD bridge program for minority students from HBCU and HSI that have graduate programs ending with M.S. degrees, specifically in the area of computational science and engineering. Finally, we provided research opportunities for local high school students so to foster their interests in predictive materials development and relate the importance of computational material science.
